author: @lfcamacho
text: In case anyone is wondering how to remove the extra zeros in the SalaryAfterRaise column, this will get it done :)  SELECT FirstName, LastName, JobTitle, Salary, CAST(CASE 	WHEN JobTitle = 'Salesman' THEN Salary + (Salary * .10) 	WHEN JobTitle = 'Accountant' THEN Salary + (Salary * .05) 	WHEN JobTitle = 'HR' THEN Salary + (Salary * .000001) 	ELSE Salary + (Salary * .03) END AS DECIMAL(18, 2)) AS SalaryAfterRaise FROM EmployeeDemographics JOIN EmployeeSalary 	ON EmployeeDemographics.EmployeeID = EmployeeSalary.EmployeeID

author: @mohammedaldufri2905
text: SELECT EmployeeID, FirstName,LastName , case  when Age > 30 THEN 'old' WHEN Age between 30 AND 35  THEN 'YOUNG' ELSE 'baby' END FROM [mine].[dbo].[EmployeeDemographics] where Age is NOT NULL ORDER BY Age With this order, if an employee's age is greater than 30, they will be categorized as "old" regardless of whether they fall within the range of 30 to 35. If the age is not greater than 30, then the next condition is checked to determine if they fall within the range of 30 to 35 and categorized as "YOUNG". If neither condition is met, they will be categorized as "baby".

author: @mohammedaldufri2905
text: select * From [mine].[dbo].[EmployeeDemographics] where Age is NOT NULL  SELECT EmployeeID, FirstName,LastName  FROM [mine].[dbo].[EmployeeDemographics] where Age is NOT NULL ORDER BY Age  SELECT EmployeeID, FirstName,LastName , case  when Age > 30 THEN 'old' ELSE 'YOUNG' END FROM [mine].[dbo].[EmployeeDemographics] where Age is NOT NULL ORDER BY Age In this query, we added a CASE statement to categorize employees into "old" or "YOUNG" based on their age. The result will include the columns EmployeeID, FirstName, LastName, and a new column called AgeGroup. The CASE statement checks if the age is greater than 30 and assigns the corresponding value. Finally, we sort the result by the Age column in ascending order.

author: @taniakresna
text: in case somebody need another simple calculation on the syntax: SELECT FirstName, LastName, JobTitle, Salary, CASE 	WHEN JobTitle = 'Salesman' THEN Salary * 1.10 	WHEN JobTitle = 'Accountant' THEN Salary * 1.05 	WHEN JobTitle = 'HR' THEN Salary * 1.000001 	ELSE Salary * 1.03 END AS SalaryAfterRaise FROM SQLTutorial.dbo.EmployeeDemographics JOIN SQLTutorial.dbo.EmployeeSalary 	ON EmployeeSalary.EmployeeID = EmployeeDemographics.EmployeeID

text: Hello Alex, This came handy for me as I was looking for a solution to  a particular task I was currently battling with. However, Can You help me with the syntax for the following task I have been struggling with for some days now?  Question 1 How many employees will be due a long service award in the next 5 years, if long service is 20 years?   Question 2 How many more years does each employee have to work before reaching sentiment, if sentiment age is 65?  Question 3 Implement a new price policy on the product table based on the colour of the item  If white increases price by 8%, If yellow reduces price by 7.5%, If black increase price by 17.2%. If multi, silver, silver/black or blue take the square root of the price and double the value. Column should be called Newprice. For each item, also calculate commission as 37.5% of newly computed list price.  Anticipating your quick esponse
